Employee Benefits & Allowances Policy 
1. Purpose 
This document outlines the various benefits, allowances, and financial support provided to 
employees as part of their overall compensation package. These benefits are designed to enhance 
employee well-being, support productivity, and promote work-life balance. 
This policy applies to all full-time employees unless otherwise specified. 
 
2. Food Allowance 
2.1 Monthly Food Allowance 
Employees may be eligible for a monthly food allowance that can be used for: 
 Lunch/meals during office hours 
 Cafeteria usage 
 Food service partners (if available) 
2.2 Allowance Amount 
 Junior staff: ₹1,000–₹2,000 per month 
 Mid-level: ₹1,500–₹2,500 per month 
 Senior staff: ₹2,000–₹3,000 per month 
(Exact values vary by company policy.) 
2.3 Meal Card / Wallet 
Companies may issue: 
 Prepaid meal cards 
 Digital food wallets 
 Sodexo/Swiggy Money vouchers 
2.4 Tax Benefit 
Meal allowance through Meal Card may be tax-exempt up to ₹50 per meal, as per Income Tax 
rules.

3. Internet / Work-From-Home Allowance 
3.1 Monthly WFH Allowance 
Employees working remotely or in hybrid mode may receive: 
 Internet allowance 
 Mobile data reimbursement 
 Electricity support (optional) 
3.2 Reimbursement Limits 
 Internet: ₹500–₹800 per month 
 Mobile bill: ₹300–₹1,000 (role-based: sales, support, managers) 
 WFH support allowance: ₹500–₹1,500 (depending on company structure) 
3.3 Claim Requirements 
 Valid invoice in employee’s name 
 Submitted within the reimbursement cut-off date 
3.4 Tax Treatment 
WFH allowances are taxable unless categorized under specific exemptions. 
 
4. Health Insurance Benefits 
4.1 Group Medical Insurance (GMI) 
All full-time employees are covered under the company’s health insurance plan. 
Coverage typically includes: 
 Inpatient hospitalization 
 Day-care procedures 
 Emergency services 
 Pre & post-hospitalization expenses 
 Cashless claim network hospitals

4.2 Coverage Amount 
 Standard employees: ₹2–₹5 lakhs 
 Senior roles: ₹5–₹10 lakhs 
 Optional top-up cover for employees and families 
4.3 Family Coverage (Optional or Employer-Sponsored) 
Coverage for: 
 Spouse 
 Children 
 Parents (optional/add-on with additional premium) 
4.4 Group Personal Accident Insurance 
Employees are insured for accidental disability or death. 
4.5 Group Term Life Insurance (Optional) 
Company may offer life insurance coverage as part of senior employee benefits. 
 
5. Leave Travel Allowance (LTA) 
5.1 Eligibility 
Employees may avail LTA as part of their CTC once or twice in a 4-year block. 
5.2 What LTA Covers 
 Travel expenses for employee and immediate family 
 Travel by: 
o Air (economy class) 
o Rail (AC Tier) 
o Bus (AC) 
5.3 What LTA Does NOT Cover 
 Hotel accommodation 
 Food expenses 
 Local travel or sightseeing 
 International travel

5.4 Claim Requirements 
 Travel tickets/boarding pass 
 Proof of travel dates 
 LTA claim form 
5.5 Tax Benefits 
LTA is tax-exempt if: 
 Travel is within India 
 Employee submits valid travel proofs 
 
6. Bonus & Incentive Programs 
6.1 Annual Performance Bonus 
Awarded based on: 
 Annual appraisal rating 
 Company performance 
 Project performance 
Typical bonus range: 
 5%–25% of annual CTC (role-based) 
6.2 Project Completion Bonus 
May be provided for: 
 Successful delivery of high-value projects 
 Special skill contributions 
6.3 Referral Bonus 
Employees who refer candidates for open positions receive: 
 ₹5,000–₹25,000 depending on job level 
 Paid after the referred employee completes probation 
6.4 Festival Bonus (Optional)

Some companies offer: 
 Diwali bonus 
 Year-end bonus 
 
7. Education & Skill Development Support 
7.1 Certification Reimbursement 
Company reimburses job-related certifications, such as: 
 AWS, Azure, GCP 
 Scrum Master, PMP 
 Cybersecurity certifications 
 Technical stack certifications 
Reimbursement limit: 
 ₹10,000–₹30,000 per year (role-based) 
7.2 Course Fee Support 
Support available for: 
 Online learning platforms (Coursera, Udemy, Pluralsight) 
 Workshops or bootcamps 
 Technical and soft-skill programs 
7.3 Eligibility 
 Employee must be confirmed or 6+ months in employment 
 Course must be directly related to role or growth path 
7.4 Conditions 
 Must pass exam or submit course completion 
 Proof of payment required 
 May require a service agreement for high-cost programs 
7.5 Learning Time Allocation 
Employees may receive:

 Learning hours per quarter 
 Access to internal L&D programs 
 Participation in tech talks, hackathons, and innovation workshops 
 
8. Additional Company Benefits (Optional) 
8.1 Provident Fund (PF) 
 Employer contribution: 12% of Basic (included in CTC) 
8.2 Gratuity 
 Payable after completing 5 years 
 4.81% of Basic added to CTC 
8.3 Paid Leaves 
 Casual Leave (CL) 
 Sick Leave (SL) 
 Privilege Leave (PL) 
 Maternity/Paternity Leave 
8.4 Employee Wellness Programs 
 Counseling/mental health sessions 
 Yoga/fitness programs 
 Medical checkup camps 
8.5 Company Events 
 Annual outing 
 Festival celebrations 
 Team lunches 
 Rewards & recognition programs 
 
9. Claim Process for Benefits & Allowances 
9.1 Standard Claim Procedure

1. Employee submits claim in HRMS 
2. Uploads valid bills 
3. Manager approves 
4. Finance validates 
5. Reimbursement processed in salary or separate cycle 
9.2 Claim Timelines 
 Claims must be submitted within 15–30 days of expense 
 Late submissions may require special approval 
9.3 Taxation Rules 
 Benefits categorized under taxable and non-taxable heads 
 Employees advised to check Form 12BB requirements 
 
10. Policy Review 
The benefits policy will be reviewed annually by HR and Finance to ensure: 
 Market competitiveness 
 Employee satisfaction 
 Legal compliance 
Updates will be communicated to all employees via email or HRMS

General Reimbursement Rules Document 
1. Purpose 
This document outlines the rules and procedures for claiming reimbursement of business-related 
expenses. It ensures transparency, fairness, and compliance with company financial policies. 
The policy applies to all full-time, part-time, contractual, probationary employees, and interns 
where applicable. 
 
2. Allowed Expenses (Reimbursable) 
Employees may claim reimbursement for business-related and pre-approved expenses only. 
2.1 Travel Expenses 
 Local travel for client meetings (Ola/Uber/Auto/Metro) 
 Outstation travel (flight/train/bus) 
 Airport/railway transfers 
 Fuel (only if approved for personal vehicle use) 
2.2 Accommodation & Meals (Business Travel) 
 Hotel stays within company limits 
 Meals consumed during official travel 
 Breakfast/lunch/dinner during client visits 
2.3 Communication Expenses 
 Official mobile/internet bills (role-based approval) 
 Data packs used for business purposes 
2.4 Office Supplies & Equipment 
 Stationery 
 Small accessories (mouse, keyboard, cables) 
 Work tools approved by manager 
2.5 Professional Expenses 
 Conference/workshop registration

Insurance & Health Coverage Policy 
1. Purpose 
The Insurance & Health Coverage Policy defines the medical, accident, and life insurance 
benefits provided to employees. The goal is to ensure financial protection, promote employee 
well-being, and support employees during medical or emergency situations. 
This policy applies to all full-time employees unless otherwise specified. 
 
2. Types of Insurance Offered 
The company typically provides three main categories of insurance: 
 
2.1 Group Medical Insurance (GMI) – Health Insurance 
Provides coverage for hospitalization and medical expenses for employees and their eligible 
dependents. 
Coverage Includes: 
 Inpatient hospitalization 
 Pre-hospitalization expenses (typically 30 days) 
 Post-hospitalization expenses (typically 60–90 days) 
 Day-care procedures 
 Room rent charges 
 Surgeries and specialist treatments 
 Emergency ambulance charges 
 Maternity benefits (optional/company-specific) 
 COVID-related claims (as per insurer policies) 
Dependent Coverage (if opted) 
 Spouse 
 Children 
 Parents (optional add-on with employee-paid premium)

2.2 Group Personal Accident Insurance (GPA) 
Covers accidental injuries, disability, or death. 
Coverage Includes: 
 Accidental death 
 Permanent total disability 
 Permanent partial disability 
 Temporary disability benefits 
 Accidental medical reimbursement (based on policy terms) 
 
2.3 Group Term Life Insurance (Optional / Role-Based) 
Provides financial protection to employee’s family in case of natural or accidental death. 
Coverage Includes: 
 Lump sum payout to nominee 
 Coverage based on grade level 
 Typically 1× to 3× of annual CTC 
 
3. Eligibility Criteria 
3.1 Full-Time Employees 
Eligible from Day 1 of joining (or from the 1st of the following month as per company policy). 
3.2 Dependents 
Eligible dependents: 
 Spouse 
 Children (up to 25 years, unmarried) 
 Parents (if company policy allows) 
3.3 Contract/Interns 
Eligibility depends on:

 Contract agreement 
 Management approval 
 Project/client requirement 
 
4. Coverage Details 
Coverage is subject to the insurer’s policy terms. 
 
4.1 Health Insurance Coverage Amount 
Typical coverage slabs (example): 
 Employee: ₹2–₹5 lakhs 
 Family floater: ₹3–₹7 lakhs 
 Optional top-up: ₹5–₹20 lakhs (employee-paid) 
 
4.2 Room Rent Limits 
 1% of sum insured for normal room 
 2% of sum insured for ICU 
(Example: ₹5 lakh coverage → ₹5,000/day room rent) 
 
4.3 Co-Payment & Exclusions 
Common exclusions: 
 Cosmetic treatments 
 Pre-existing diseases within waiting period 
 Non-medical items (gloves, masks, toiletries) 
 Dental and vision (unless covered) 
Co-payment may apply for: 
 Parental insurance 
 Special procedure add-ons

4.4 Accident Insurance Coverage 
Examples: 
 Accidental death: 100% of sum insured 
 Total disability: 100% 
 Partial disability: % based on injury table 
 
4.5 Life Insurance Coverage 
Typically covers: 
 Natural death 
 Accidental death 
 Suicide after waiting period (as per IRDA rules) 
Coverage value varies by employee level. 
 
5. Claim Process 
Employees must follow the insurer’s claim guidelines. 
 
5.1 Cashless Claim Procedure 
Used when hospitalized at a network hospital. 
Steps to follow: 
1. Inform HR/insurance desk immediately. 
2. Provide health card/employee ID at reception. 
3. Hospital submits pre-authorization to insurer. 
4. Insurer approves cashless treatment. 
5. Employee pays only non-covered expenses.

5.2 Reimbursement Claim Procedure 
Used when cashless is not available. 
Required documents: 
 Hospital bills (original) 
 Discharge summary 
 Diagnostic reports 
 Doctor prescriptions 
 Payment receipts 
 Claim form (signed) 
Steps: 
1. Pay the hospital bill at discharge. 
2. Submit all documents to HR/insurance team. 
3. HR forwards to insurer/TPA. 
4. Reimbursement credited to employee’s bank account. 
Processing time: 15–30 working days. 
 
5.3 Accident Insurance Claim 
Steps: 
1. Inform HR within 24–48 hours of accident. 
2. Submit FIR (if applicable), medical reports, bills. 
3. Insurer evaluates disability percentage. 
4. Claim payout made to employee/nominee. 
 
5.4 Life Insurance Claim 
Steps: 
1. Nominee informs HR. 
2. Submit death certificate & claim form. 
3. HR coordinates with insurance provider. 
4. Benefit amount paid directly to nominee.

6. Documents Required for Claims 
Standard documents may include: 
 Claim form (signed by employee/HR) 
 ID proof & insurance card 
 Doctor’s consultation papers 
 Pharmacy bills with prescriptions 
 Hospital bill summary & receipts 
 Diagnostic reports 
 Death certificate (for life insurance) 
 FIR or accident report (for accident claims) 
All documents must be legible and in original (if required). 
 
7. Employee Responsibilities 
Employees must: 
 Notify HR before or immediately after hospitalization 
 Use their health card for cashless facilities 
 Submit correct and original documents 
 Follow insurer’s rules & timelines 
 Pay for exclusions or non-medical items 
 Update nominee details annually 
 
8. HR/Company Responsibilities 
HR will: 
 Facilitate insurance onboarding 
 Maintain employee/dependent records 
 Assist in claim submissions 
 Conduct insurance awareness sessions 
 Coordinate with TPA for escalations 
 Provide timely updates on renewal/change in coverage

9. Exclusions & Limitations 
The following are typically not covered: 
 Non-prescribed medicines 
 Cosmetic or voluntary procedures 
 Self-inflicted injuries 
 Pre-existing diseases (during waiting period) 
 Treatments outside India (unless covered by policy) 
 OPD consultations (unless included) 
Each insurer’s policy document prevails over general guidelines. 
 
10. Policy Review 
HR and the insurance partner will review the policy: 
 Annually during renewal 
 After major regulatory changes 
 Based on employee feedback 
Updates will be shared via email/HRMS.

Payroll Cycle & Salary Breakdown Policy 
1. Purpose 
The purpose of this policy is to define how employee salaries are structured, calculated, and 
processed each month. It ensures transparency in payroll cycles, statutory deductions, overtime 
rules, and payslip components. 
 
2. Payroll Cycle 
2.1 Monthly Payroll Timeline 
 Payroll Period: 1st to 30th/31st of every month 
 Payroll Processing: 25th–30th (internal processing) 
 Salary Credit Date: On or before the 7th of each month 
 Payslip Release: Within 2 working days of salary credit 
2.2 Cut-Off Dates 
For accurate payroll processing: 
 Attendance cut-off: 25th of every month 
 Reimbursement cut-off: Last working day 
 Leave approvals must be updated before payroll cut-off 
 
3. Salary Structure (CTC Breakdown) 
CTC (Cost to Company) includes all fixed and variable components payable to the employee 
annually. 
3.1 Standard CTC Components 
CTC may be structured as follows: 
A. Fixed Pay Components 
1. Basic Salary 
o Typically 35–50% of CTC

o Fully taxable 
2. House Rent Allowance (HRA) 
o 40–50% of Basic (based on city) 
o Tax exemption available under Income Tax rules 
3. Conveyance Allowance / Transport Allowance 
o As per company norms 
o Taxable 
4. Special Allowance / Flexi Allowance 
o Balancing component of CTC 
o Fully taxable 
5. Medical Allowance (Optional) 
o Taxable 
B. Variable Pay Components 
 Performance Bonus 
 Quarterly/Annual Incentives 
 Project allowances (role-based) 
 Shift allowances (if applicable) 
C. Statutory Benefits (Employer Contribution) 
Included in CTC: 
 Employer PF contribution (12% of Basic) 
 ESI (if applicable) 
 Gratuity (4.81% of Basic annually) 
 
4. Overtime Rules 
Overtime (OT) is allowed only for eligible employees (non-managerial/operations roles). 
4.1 Eligibility 
 Must be pre-approved by the Reporting Manager 
 OT applies only beyond standard working hours 
 Not applicable for managerial or exempt employees 
4.2 OT Calculation 
 OT Rate = (Monthly Gross Salary / 26 days / 8 hours) × 2 (double rate) 
 OT is payable for: 
o Weekend work (if not weekly off)

o Holiday work 
o Extra hours beyond 9 working hours 
4.3 Compensatory Off 
 Employees may receive Comp-Off instead of OT payment (manager-approved) 
 
5. Statutory Deductions 
All payroll deductions are made as per Indian law. 
 
5.1 Provident Fund (PF) 
 Employee contribution: 12% of Basic 
 Employer contribution: 12% of Basic (part of CTC) 
 Mandatory for salaries under ₹15,000 Basic (voluntary beyond this limit) 
 
5.2 Employee State Insurance (ESI) 
Applicable if gross salary ≤ ₹21,000/month. 
 Employee contribution: 0.75% of gross 
 Employer contribution: 3.25% of gross 
 
5.3 Professional Tax (PT) 
 Applicable in certain states (Maharashtra, Karnataka, West Bengal, etc.) 
 Deducted monthly as per state slab 
 
5.4 Tax Deducted at Source (TDS) 
 Deducted as per Income Tax Act 
 Calculated monthly based on declared investments

 Employees must submit: 
o Form 12BB 
o Proof of investment/savings 
 
5.5 Other Deductions 
 Loss of Pay (LOP) for unapproved leave 
 Loan/advance EMI (if applicable) 
 Notice period recovery (if applicable) 
 Asset recovery (if applicable) 
 
6. Payslip Details 
Payslips are issued monthly and include the following: 
6.1 Employee Information 
 Employee Name 
 Employee Code 
 Designation 
 Bank Account Details 
 PAN & UAN (PF number) 
6.2 Salary Components 
Earnings: 
 Basic Salary 
 HRA 
 Conveyance Allowance 
 Special Allowance 
 Performance Pay / Bonus (if applicable) 
Deductions: 
 PF Contribution 
 ESI Contribution 
 Professional Tax 
 TDS 
 LOP Days Deduction 
 Other deductions

6.3 Net Salary 
Net Salary = Gross Salary – Total Deductions 
6.4 Year-to-Date (YTD) Data 
Payslip should display: 
 Total earnings 
 Total deductions 
 Total PF/ESI contributions 
 Tax deducted till date 
 
7. Payroll Compliance Rules 
7.1 Attendance 
Employees must: 
 Log attendance daily 
 Apply leaves through HRMS 
 Ensure manager approvals 
Incorrect or missing attendance may lead to: 
 LOP 
 Delay in salary credit 
7.2 Bank Details 
Employees must provide: 
 Valid bank account number 
 IFSC code 
 Cancelled cheque 
Any change must be pre-approved by HR. 
 
8. Payroll Issue Resolution

8.1 Common Payroll Queries 
 Delay in salary 
 Incorrect deduction 
 PF/ESI query 
 TDS calculation 
8.2 Contact 
Employees must raise payroll queries to: 
 payroll@[company].com 
 HR helpdesk ticketing system 
Response time: 3–5 working days 
 
9. End-of-Year Payroll Components 
9.1 Form 16 
Issued annually before 30 June for tax filing. 
9.2 Investment Declaration 
Employees must: 
 Submit declarations at the start of the financial year 
 Provide proofs before January each year 
9.3 Final Settlement (On Resignation) 
Includes: 
 Pending salary 
 Leave encashment 
 Bonus/variable pay (if applicable) 
 Deductions for notice period, assets, etc. 
 
10. Policy Review

This policy is reviewed annually by HR & Finance to ensure compliance with: 
 Income Tax Act 
 EPFO regulations 
 ESIC guidelines 
 State Professional Tax laws

Disciplinary Action Policy 
1. Purpose 
This policy outlines the standards of conduct expected from employees and the disciplinary 
actions that may be taken when these standards are violated. 
The objective is to maintain fairness, consistency, and transparency across the organization. 
This policy applies to all employees—full-time, part-time, interns, trainees, and contractors. 
 
2. Types of Misconduct 
Misconduct refers to any behavior that violates company policies, ethical standards, or 
workplace expectations. It is categorized into minor and major misconduct. 
 
2.1 Minor Misconduct 
Minor misconduct includes behaviors that do not pose serious harm but affect productivity, 
discipline, or work environment. 
Examples of Minor Misconduct 
 Frequent late arrival 
 Unapproved short absence 
 Failure to follow instructions 
 Minor breach of processes 
 Misuse of office time (excessive personal calls) 
 Negligence in completing tasks 
 Inappropriate language or unprofessional behavior 
 Minor violation of IT/attendance policies 
Minor misconduct usually results in corrective counseling or progressive warnings. 
 
2.2 Major Misconduct 
Major misconduct includes actions that are serious, intentional, or cause harm to the company, 
its employees, or reputation.

Examples of Major Misconduct 
 Theft, fraud, forgery, or misappropriation 
 Harassment, bullying, threats, discrimination 
 Violation of POSH (Sexual Harassment) guidelines 
 Physical violence or abusive behavior 
 Data theft, confidentiality breach, security violations 
 Tampering with attendance systems 
 Substance abuse within work premises 
 Gross insubordination 
 Repeated minor misconduct 
 Unauthorized absence for multiple days 
 Violating safety rules resulting in harm 
Major misconduct may lead to suspension, termination, or legal action. 
 
3. Disciplinary Actions 
The company adopts a progressive discipline system, but reserves the right to skip steps for 
severe violations. 
 
3.1 Verbal Warning 
Purpose 
Given for first instances of minor misconduct or performance issues. 
Process 
 Manager provides verbal feedback and corrective instructions 
 Details may be recorded in HRMS for internal tracking 
 Employee is informed that repeated issues will escalate 
Example 
“Employee repeatedly arrives 20–30 minutes late without proper communication.” 
 
3.2 Written Warning

Issued When: 
 Conduct does not improve after a verbal warning 
 Misconduct has higher severity 
 Attendance or behavior repeatedly violates policy 
Contents of Written Warning 
 Description of violation 
 Expectations for correction 
 Time frame for improvement 
 Consequences if behavior continues 
Employee Acknowledgement 
Employee must sign the written warning (or HR records refusal to sign). 
 
3.3 Suspension 
When Applied 
Suspension may be used during: 
 Investigation of major misconduct 
 Serious violations posing risk to safety, data, or reputation 
 Continued misconduct after warnings 
Terms 
 Employee may be suspended with or without pay based on severity 
 Suspension duration typically ranges 3–14 days 
 Employee must remain available for meetings or inquiries 
Example 
“Employee accessing and sharing confidential client data without authorization.” 
 
3.4 Termination 
Grounds for Termination

 Severe misconduct 
 Repeated violations despite warnings 
 Breach of confidentiality or security 
 Harassment or assault 
 Falsification of company records or documents 
 Unauthorized absence beyond acceptable limits 
 Any action causing financial or reputational damage 
Procedure 
 After inquiry, HR issues a termination letter 
 Full & final settlement processed as per policy 
 Company assets must be returned prior to relieving 
Termination may occur with immediate effect in extreme cases. 
 
4. Investigation Process 
The company ensures a fair and unbiased investigation before imposing any major disciplinary 
action. 
4.1 Steps in Investigation 
1. Complaint/Incident Report Received 
o By manager, HR, or employee 
2. Preliminary Review 
o HR assesses severity & determines if formal investigation is required 
3. Formation of Investigation Panel 
o Typically includes HR, senior manager, or compliance officer 
4. Collection of Evidence 
o Emails, chats, system logs, CCTV (if applicable) 
5. Employee & Witness Interviews 
o Both complainant and alleged employee are heard separately 
6. Documentation 
o Findings are recorded and reviewed 
7. Decision & Recommendation 
o Based on evidence, proportional disciplinary action is proposed 
8. Implementation 
o HR issues warning, suspension, or termination 
4.2 Timeline

 Investigations should ideally be completed within 7–15 working days, depending on 
complexity. 
4.3 Fairness & Transparency 
 Both parties have the right to present their statements 
 No disciplinary action is taken on assumptions without evidence 
 
5. Escalation Hierarchy

 Provides verbal feedback or initial corrective actions 
5.2 Level 2 – HR Department

 Guides managers on policy compliance 
5.3 Level 3 – Department Head / Functional Lead

Process

 Receive written communication about disciplinary actions 
 Appeal decisions (if appeal process exists in company policy)

Acts of retaliation (isolation, threats, unfair ratings) will result in strict disciplinary action. 
 
8. Confidentiality 
All disciplinary matters will be handled confidentially.

9. Record Keeping 
HR will maintain confidential records of: 
 Complaints 
 Investigation findings 
 Warning letters 
 Suspension and termination documents

Leave & Attendance Policy 
1. Introduction 
This Leave & Attendance Policy outlines the rules for leave entitlement, attendance 
requirements, and leave-related procedures for all employees. The aim is to maintain fairness, 
transparency, and operational efficiency. 
This policy applies to all permanent, probationary, full-time, and contract employees unless 
stated otherwise. 
 
2. Types of Leaves 
2.1 Casual Leave (CL) 
 Employees are entitled to 12 Casual Leaves per calendar year. 
 CL is meant for short-term personal needs, emergencies, or urgent commitments. 
 Maximum 2 consecutive CLs can be availed at a time unless approved by the manager. 
 CL cannot be clubbed with PL unless specially approved by HR. 
 Unused CLs cannot be encashed. 
 Carry forward of CL is not permitted in most IT policies unless company-specific 
exception exists. 
 
2.2 Privilege Leave (PL) / Earned Leave (EL) 
 Employees are entitled to 12 Privilege Leaves annually (or as per state laws applicable). 
 PL must be applied at least 7 days in advance except in emergencies. 
 Minimum PL application: 1 full day. 
 Maximum PL in one stretch: not more than 14 days, unless managerial approval is 
provided. 
 Unused PL may be: 
o Carried forward up to 30 days (commonly used limit) OR 
o Encashed annually or during full & final settlement (subject to company rules). 
 
2.3 Sick Leave (SL)

 Employees are entitled to 12 Sick Leaves per year. 
 SL is meant strictly for medical issues. 
 Medical certificate is mandatory if: 
o SL exceeds 2 consecutive days, OR 
o Frequent sickness patterns are observed. 
 SL cannot be encashed. 
 SL may carry forward up to 30 days, depending on company policy. 
 
3. Leave Carry Forward & Encashment 
3.1 Carry Forward 
Leave Type Carry Forward Max Limit 
Casual Leave ❌ Not allowed 0 
Sick Leave ✔️ Allowed (optional) 30 days 
Privilege Leave ✔️ Allowed 30–45 days (company-specific) 
3.2 Encashment 
 Only Privilege Leave (PL) may be encashed. 
 Encashment may occur: 
o At end of financial year 
o On resignation (part of full & final settlement) 
 Encashment is typically at basic salary rate. 
 
4. Sandwich Leave Rule 
The Sandwich Rule is applied when an employee takes leave immediately before and after a 
holiday/weekend. 
4.1 Example 
 Friday – Leave 
 Saturday – Weekly Off 
 Sunday – Weekly Off 
 Monday – Leave 
→ In this case, Saturday + Sunday will also count as leave, making it a 4-day leave.

4.2 Applicability 
The Sandwich Rule applies when: 
 CL or PL is taken both days around a weekend or holiday 
 Festival or national holidays fall in between leave periods 
4.3 Exceptions 
 Medical emergencies with proper documentation 
 Maternity leave 
 HR-approved travel situations 
 
5. Half-Day Leave Policy 
5.1 When Half-Day Leave is Allowed 
A half-day can be availed for: 
 Personal work 
 Medical appointments 
 Delayed arrival or early departure 
5.2 Timing Rules 
 Arrival after 2 hours of shift start → Half-day counted 
 Early departure more than 2 hours before shift end → Half-day counted 
 If employee logs less than 4.5 hours, full-day leave is deducted. 
5.3 Approval 
Half-day must be approved by: 
 Reporting Manager 
 Marked in attendance system 
 
6. Attendance Tracking Policy 
6.1 Working Hours

 Standard shift: 9 hours including breaks 
 Core working hours: 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM 
6.2 Attendance System 
Employees must mark attendance through: 
 Biometric device 
 Mobile/Geo attendance app 
 Web-based attendance portal 
6.3 Late Mark Rules 
 3 late marks = ½ day leave deduction. 
 More than 10 late marks/month → HR counselling. 
 Late arrival should be communicated to the reporting manager in advance. 
6.4 Weekly Off and Holiday Attendance 
Weekly offs are based on: 
 5-day work week: Saturday & Sunday 
 6-day work week: Sunday 
Public holidays will be announced at the start of the year. 
 
7. Leave Without Pay (LWP / LOP) 
7.1 When LOP Is Applied 
 Absence when no leave balance is available 
 Unapproved absence 
 Unexplained absence for more than 1 day 
 Failure to apply for leave as per policy 
 Frequent short leaves without justification 
7.2 Calculation 
LOP is calculated on: 
 Monthly salary / Number of days in the month 
 Salary deductions will reflect in the next payroll cycle

7.3 Key Outcomes of LOP 
 Impacts salary 
 Impacts performance evaluation if repeated 
 May affect appraisal cycle 
 
8. Unapproved Absence Policy 
8.1 Definition 
Unapproved absence refers to an employee not reporting to work without: 
 Manager approval 
 HR notification 
 Valid reason 
8.2 Disciplinary Action 
If unapproved absence continues for: 
 3 consecutive days → Written warning 
 5 consecutive days → HR escalation 
 7+ days → Termination possible under “absconding from work” 
 
9. Leave Application Procedure 
9.1 Employees Must 
 Apply for leave via HR portal/app 
 Inform reporting manager 
 Attach medical documents when required 
9.2 Managers Must 
 Accept/reject leave within 24 hours 
 Ensure team coverage

10. Special Leaves (Optional, Company-
Specific) 
Some companies also offer: 
 Maternity Leave (26 weeks) 
 Paternity Leave (5–10 days) 
 Compensatory Off (for approved overtime) 
 Bereavement Leave (3–5 days) 
These can be added based on your company's policy. 
 
11. Policy Violations 
Violations include: 
 Misuse of leave 
 Fake medical certificates 
 Frequent absenteeism 
 Manipulation of attendance logs 
Disciplinary actions may range from: 
 Warning 
 Leave deduction 
 LOP 
 Impact on bonuses 
 Termination (in extreme cases) 
12. Policy Review & Amendments 
The company reserves the right to revise or update the Leave & Attendance Policy based on: 
 Business needs 
 Legal changes 
 HR audit findings 
Employees will be notified of any major changes.

Employee Exit & Separation Policy

The purpose of this policy is to provide a transparent, structured, and fair process for employee 
separation, whether voluntary or involuntary.

of dues.

probationers.

 Non-renewal of contract 
 Absconding or abandonment of employment

 Employee must submit a formal resignation in writing or via email to their Reporting 
Manager with a copy to HR. 
 The resignation date is considered the date HR receives the official notice. 
3.2 Acceptance 
 Manager reviews and acknowledges resignation within 2–3 working days. 
 HR confirms acceptance and initiates the exit workflow in HRMS. 
3.3 Notice Period Service 
 Employee must serve the required notice period as per appointment letter.

 During notice: 
o Work must continue professionally 
o Handover must be completed 
o No new long-term responsibilities are assigned unless necessary

 Manager prepares a handover plan 
 Employee cooperates in knowledge transfer 
 Successor or team members are briefed

 Probationary employees: 15 to 30 days 
 Senior management: 60 to 90 days

Allowed based on: 
 Project requirements 
 Manager and HR approval

 Excessive absence may extend notice period

5. Absconding / Abandonment of 
Employment

An employee is considered absconding when: 
 Absent from work for 3 consecutive working days 
 No communication to manager or HR 
 Non-responsive to calls, emails, or messages 
5.2 Company Procedure 
If absconding is suspected: 
1. HR sends 1st warning email on Day 3 
2. If no response, a 2nd notice is sent by Day 5 
3. If no communication continues, a Termination for Abandonment letter is issued by 
Day 7 or as per company norms 
5.3 Consequences 
 Employee may lose pending salary and benefits 
 Service certificate may not be provided 
 Future employment verification may reflect “absconding” 
 Company may take legal action if assets/data are not returned

 Performance issues 
 Policy violations 
 Misconduct or fraud 
 Harassment or code of conduct violations 
 Redundancy, restructuring, or business closure 
 Breach of confidentiality 
6.2 Termination Process

1. Investigation (if needed for misconduct cases) 
2. Manager & HR review findings 
3. Opportunity to be heard (except in severe cases) 
4. Final decision by HR and Management 
5. Termination letter issued with reason and relieving date 
6.3 Notice Period for Termination 
 Company may choose to provide: 
o Notice period as per contract, OR 
o Salary in lieu of notice 
6.4 Immediate Termination (Zero Notice) 
Applicable in cases of: 
 Data theft 
 Fraud 
 Physical violence 
 Serious misconduct 
 Gross violation of company policy 
 
7. Exit Interview Process 
7.1 Purpose 
Exit interviews are conducted to: 
 Understand reasons for separation 
 Identify improvement areas in management, culture, or processes 
 Maintain positive relations with departing employees 
7.2 Conducted By 
 HR Manager 
 Senior HR Executive 
7.3 Format 
 In-person meeting or virtual call

Anti-Harassment & Prevention of Sexual 
Harassment (POSH) Policy 
(Compliant with Indian POSH Act, 2013) 
1. Purpose 
This policy ensures a safe, respectful, and inclusive workplace, free from any form of 
harassment, discrimination, bullying, or sexual misconduct. 
It outlines the prevention, reporting, and redressal process for sexual harassment as mandated by 
Indian law. 
This policy applies to all employees, including full-time, part-time, interns, consultants, vendors, 
and anyone interacting with the company. 
 
2. Scope of the Policy 
This policy covers inappropriate behavior occurring: 
 At workplace 
 During work-from-home or hybrid mode 
 During official travel 
 At client sites 
 During office events, training, conferences, or gatherings 
 Through digital communication (email, WhatsApp, Teams, calls, messages) 
 
3. Definitions of Harassment 
3.1 Harassment 
Harassment includes any unwelcome, hostile, humiliating, intimidating, or offensive behavior 
that affects an employee’s dignity or work environment. 
Examples include: 
 Bullying, verbal abuse, shouting 
 Derogatory comments or slurs

 Threats, humiliation, or intimidation 
 Spreading rumors or personal attacks 
 Intentional exclusion or isolation 
 
3.2 Sexual Harassment (As per POSH Act, 2013) 
Sexual harassment includes any unwelcome: 
 Physical contact or advancing 
 Demands/requests for sexual favors 
 Sexually colored remarks 
 Showing pornography or explicit content 
 Any physical, verbal, non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature 
Quid Pro Quo Sexual Harassment 
“When job benefits, promotions, or work assignments are offered in exchange for sexual favors.” 
Hostile Work Environment Sexual Harassment 
“When sexually offensive behavior creates an intimidating, hostile, or humiliating environment.” 
 
4. Examples of Sexual Harassment 
4.1 Physical Conduct 
 Unwanted touching, hugging, patting 
 Brushing against someone intentionally 
 Invading personal space 
4.2 Verbal Conduct 
 Sexual jokes, stories, or comments 
 Remarks about someone’s body or appearance 
 Suggestive or inappropriate compliments 
 Asking about sexual preferences or personal life 
4.3 Non-Verbal Conduct 
 Staring, leering, stalking

 Displaying sexual materials (photos, screensavers, posters) 
 Sending inappropriate emojis, GIFs, videos 
4.4 Digital/Electronic Harassment 
 Sending explicit messages or images 
 Unwanted late-night texts or calls 
 Sharing inappropriate memes or content 
4.5 Retaliatory Behavior 
 Threats of poor appraisal 
 Withdrawal of responsibilities 
 Verbal abuse or isolation after refusal 
 
5. Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) 
The company will constitute an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) as required by law. 
5.1 ICC Composition 
1. Presiding Officer (Woman) – Senior female employee 
2. Internal Member(s) – Employees committed to women’s welfare, HR, or legal 
3. External Member – From NGO/association working for women’s rights 
4. At least 50% of ICC members must be women 
5.2 ICC Responsibilities 
 Receive and acknowledge complaints 
 Conduct fair, unbiased investigations 
 Maintain confidentiality 
 Recommend corrective actions 
 Submit annual POSH report to authorities 
 
6. Reporting Workflow 
6.1 Who Can File a Complaint? 
 Any aggrieved woman (employee, intern, consultant) 
 A witness or colleague

 A legal representative (in special cases) 
6.2 How to File a Complaint 
Complaints may be submitted through: 
 Email to ICC or HR 
 In writing (signed physical complaint) 
 Verbal complaint (ICC will assist in documentation) 
6.3 Complaint Filing Timeline 
Complaint should be filed within 3 months of the incident. 
Extensions allowed if valid reasons exist (up to 3 more months). 
6.4 Content Required in Complaint 
 Description of incident(s) 
 Date, time, location 
 Name(s) of individuals involved 
 Witnesses (if any) 
 Any supporting evidence (screenshots, messages, emails) 
 
7. Investigation Process 
7.1 Preliminary Steps 
 ICC reviews complaint 
 Written acknowledgment sent to complainant 
 Notice sent to respondent within 7 days 
7.2 Formal Inquiry 
 Respondent must respond within 10 days 
 ICC meets both parties separately 
 Witnesses may be interviewed 
 Evidence may be collected 
 Neutral, unbiased questioning ensured 
7.3 Timeline 
The investigation must be completed within 90 days, as mandated by POSH Act.

7.4 Interim Relief (If Needed) 
The complainant may request: 
 Transfer of self or respondent 
 Change of reporting manager 
 Leave up to 3 months 
 Temporary relocation 
7.5 Inquiry Findings 
After inquiry: 
 ICC prepares a written report 
 Recommendations are submitted to HR/Management within 10 days 
 
8. Possible Outcomes & Actions 
If the allegation is proven, actions may include: 
 Written apology 
 Warning or counseling 
 Salary deduction 
 Suspension 
 Demotion 
 Termination 
 Legal action (if applicable) 
If the allegation is not proven, ICC may: 
 Close the case 
 Recommend workplace mediation 
 Protect complainant from retaliation 
Malicious complaints 
If a complaint is found intentionally false (rare), disciplinary action may be taken – but lack of 
evidence alone does NOT count as malicious intent. 
 
9. Protection Against Retaliation

No employee should face retaliation for: 
 Filing a complaint 
 Supporting a colleague 
 Being a witness 
 Participating in an inquiry 
Retaliation includes: 
 Threats 
 Workplace isolation 
 Negative performance reviews 
 Reduction in responsibilities 
Any retaliatory act will result in disciplinary action against the offender. 
 
10. Confidentiality Rules 
All parties involved must maintain strict confidentiality. 
Strictly Confidential Items 
 Names of complainant and respondent 
 Witness identities 
 Details of complaint 
 Investigation notes 
 ICC findings and recommendations 
Breach of Confidentiality May Lead To: 
 Disciplinary action 
 Penalties under POSH Act 
 
11. Training & Awareness 
The company will: 
 Conduct POSH training annually 
 Display POSH policy in common areas 
 Provide new employee induction on POSH compliance

 Ensure ICC members receive formal training 
 
12. Policy Review 
This policy will be reviewed annually to ensure compliance with: 
 Indian POSH Act, 2013 
 Supreme Court guidelines 
 Company’s HR standards

Appraisal & KRA Guidelines Document 
1. Purpose

cycle, KRA-setting guidelines, rating methodology, promotion rules, and salary increment 
conditions.

organizational goals. 
 
2. Annual Performance Review Cycle 
The company follows a yearly appraisal cycle divided into the following phases: 
2.1 Goal Setting (April) 
 Employees and managers jointly define KRAs, KPIs, and competencies. 
 KRAs should align with business goals and the employee’s job description. 
2.2 Mid-Year Review (October) 
 Feedback session between manager and employee. 
 Captures progress, challenges, and support needed. 
 KRAs may be revised if business priorities change. 
2.3 Annual Review (March) 
 Final evaluation of goal achievements and performance. 
 Self-appraisal submission by employee. 
 Manager appraisal followed by calibration with HR. 
2.4 Appraisal Distribution (April/May) 
 Salary increments, bonuses, and promotions communicated. 
 
3. KRA (Key Result Area) Formation 
Guidelines

KRAs define what an employee must achieve during the appraisal period. 
3.1 KRA Framework 
KRAs must be: 
 S – Specific 
 M – Measurable 
 A – Achievable 
 R – Relevant 
 T – Time-bound 
3.2 Mandatory KRA Categories 
Typically, each role will have KRAs under: 
1. Technical/Functional Deliverables (40–60%) 
2. Quality & Productivity (10–20%) 
3. Teamwork & Collaboration (10–20%) 
4. Client/Stakeholder Satisfaction (10–20%) 
5. Innovation/Initiatives/Process Improvement (optional) 
3.3 Number of KRAs 
 Minimum: 4 
 Maximum: 7 
 Weightage assigned to each KRA must total 100% 
3.4 Examples of KRAs 
Developer: 
 Deliver 95% of sprint tasks on time with <5% defect leakage. 
 Improve module performance by 20% over baseline. 
QA Engineer: 
 Achieve 98% test coverage for assigned modules. 
 Reduce regression cycle time by 15%. 
Manager: 
 Maintain CSAT score >4.5/5. 
 Ensure project delivery within budget and timeline.

4. Performance Rating Scale

4 – Exceeds Expectations Above expected performance Strong performer, consistent excellence 
3 – Meets Expectations Meets all job requirements Solid performer, reliable 
2 – Needs Improvement Partially meets expectations Some concerns or inconsistencies 
1 – Unsatisfactory Does not meet expectations Serious performance issues

 Consistency 
 Behavior & adherence to company values 
 Client feedback 
 Initiative, learning & ownership

Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) Policy 
1. Purpose 
The Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) Policy outlines a structured process to help employees 
improve their performance when it does not meet expected standards. The purpose of a PIP is 
corrective—not punitive—and aims to give employees clarity, support, and measurable goals to 
succeed. 
 
2. Eligibility for PIP 
Employees may be placed on a PIP if: 
2.1 Performance Concerns 
 Consistently not meeting KRAs/KPIs 
 Low productivity or repeated missed deadlines 
 Poor quality of work or high defect rate 
 Failure to adapt to role expectations 
2.2 Behavioral or Professional Issues 
 Lack of accountability or ownership 
 Inadequate communication or teamwork 
 Non-adherence to company processes 
2.3 After Appraisal 
 Rating of Needs Improvement or Unsatisfactory 
 Manager recommendation based on performance review 
2.4 Exclusions 
Employees should not be placed on a PIP if: 
 They have not received clear feedback prior to evaluation 
 Undergoing major personal/medical challenges (case-by-case) 
 They have been in the role for less than 60 days (except major issues)

3. PIP Duration & Structure (30–60–90 Days) 
A PIP typically lasts 30, 60, or 90 days, depending on performance gaps and job complexity. 
3.1 30-Day PIP 
Used when: 
 Issues are minor but need quick correction 
 Employee has shown some improvement already 
 Only specific tasks or behaviors need focus 
3.2 60-Day PIP 
Used when: 
 Multiple KRAs/KPIs require improvement 
 Employee requires more structured support 
3.3 90-Day PIP 
Used when: 
 Large performance gaps exist 
 Employee needs sustained improvement 
 Role responsibilities are complex 
 
4. PIP Plan Structure 
Each PIP must include: 
4.1 Performance Gaps Identified 
Clear documentation of: 
 What is not meeting expectations 
 Examples of challenges or issues 
 Related KPIs or behaviors 
4.2 Improvement Objectives

All objectives must be: 
 Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound (SMART) 
4.3 Action Plan 
Manager must specify: 
 Training requirements 
 Resources or support needed 
 Mentorship or buddy assignment 
 Tools or access required 
4.4 Success Criteria 
Examples: 
 Complete 95% of assigned sprint tasks 
 Reduce defect rate by 50% 
 Improve communication responsiveness within 2 hours 
 Ensure zero missed deadlines for the next 4 weeks 
4.5 Timeline & Milestones 
Defined checkpoints such as: 
 Week 2 review 
 Mid-cycle evaluation (Day 15/30/45) 
 Final review meeting 
 
5. Review Meetings During PIP 
Review meetings are mandatory for transparency and improvement tracking. 
5.1 Weekly Check-ins 
 Discuss completed tasks 
 Identify blockers 
 Provide guidance and feedback 
 Document progress 
5.2 Mid-Point Review

Based on plan duration: 
 30-day PIP → Day 15 
 60-day PIP → Day 30 
 90-day PIP → Day 45 
Purpose: 
 Evaluate progress 
 Adjust PIP goals if needed 
 Provide additional support 
5.3 Final Review Meeting 
Held within 3 days of PIP completion. 
Manager and HR review: 
 Objective achievements 
 Behavior improvements 
 Feedback from stakeholders 
Final outcome is documented and communicated to the employee. 
 
6. Documentation Rules 
Proper documentation is mandatory to ensure fairness and compliance. 
6.1 Mandatory Documents 
 PIP initiation form 
 Performance gap analysis 
 Improvement objectives & success criteria 
 Weekly review notes / meeting minutes 
 Mid-cycle and final evaluation reports 
 Employee acknowledgement (signature/email confirmation) 
6.2 Storage 
All PIP documents must be: 
 Uploaded to HRMS 
 Stored in the employee’s digital personnel file

 Accessible only to HR, reporting manager, and department head 
6.3 Communication 
 All PIP communication must be in writing 
 Oral conversations should be followed with email summary 
Lack of documentation invalidates the PIP process. 
 
7. Outcomes of PIP 
At the end of the PIP period, outcomes may include: 
7.1 Successful Completion 
Employee meets all defined goals. 
Results: 
 Employee continues in the role 
 Performance rating improves 
 No further corrective action is taken 
 Employee may be considered for future growth 
7.2 Partial Improvement 
Employee shows progress but not fully meets expectations. 
Actions: 
 Extend PIP for additional 30–45 days 
 Provide further training or mentoring 
 Define objective gaps that remain 
7.3 Unsuccessful PIP 
If employee fails to meet expectations despite support: 
Possible Actions: 
1. Role Reassignment

o Move to a role better suited to skills (if available) 
2. Demotion 
o Assign simpler responsibilities with adjusted compensation 
3. Separation (Termination) 
o If performance does not improve, employment may be terminated 
o HR will issue termination with proper notice or salary in lieu 
Termination due to unsuccessful PIP is considered: 
 Performance-based 
 Not a disciplinary or misconduct action 
 
8. Exit Criteria for Unsuccessful PIP 
An employee may be separated if: 
 60–80% of PIP objectives are not met 
 Performance remains inconsistent or below acceptable level 
 Employee fails to attend PIP meetings 
 No improvement is demonstrated despite training/support 
 Poor quality of work impacts project/client deliverables 
Termination Process 
 Manager submits final PIP evaluation to HR 
 HR reviews documentation for fairness and compliance 
 Department head approves final decision 
 Employee receives formal separation letter 
 Exit & handover process begins 
 
9. Roles & Responsibilities

 Understand goals and expectations 
 Attend all review meetings 
 Provide updates honestly 
 Take ownership of improvement

 Provide clear feedback 
 Create realistic PIP objectives 
 Offer resources and support 
 Document every step 
 Evaluate impartially 
HR 
 Ensure process fairness 
 Monitor timelines 
 Facilitate documentation 
 Approve/validate PIP initiation and closure 
 Participate in final PIP review

Security & Confidentiality Policy 
(For SlipSho Technologies Pvt. Ltd.) 
1. Purpose 
This policy defines the security standards required to protect company data, client information, 
intellectual property, and IT systems. It ensures that all employees follow best practices for 
secure handling, storage, and transmission of confidential information. 
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, interns, vendors, and anyone accessing 
company systems. 
 
2. Data Classification 
All company data must be categorized into the following levels: 
2.1 Public Data 
 Can be shared externally without restrictions 
 Examples: company website content, marketing materials 
2.2 Internal Data 
 Restricted to employees only 
 Examples: internal policies, training materials, project schedules 
2.3 Confidential Data 
 Restricted to authorized teams 
 Requires approval for internal circulation 
 Examples: source code, client documentation, business plans, designs 
2.4 Highly Confidential / Restricted 
 Access granted on a strict need-to-know basis 
 Must be encrypted in transit & at rest 
 Examples: financial records, employee data, contracts, credentials, API keys 
Employees must always know what classification they are handling.

3. Password Rules 
To maintain system security, employees must follow these rules: 
3.1 Password Requirements 
 Minimum 8–12 characters 
 Must include uppercase, lowercase, number, special character 
 Must not contain personal information (names, birthdays, etc.) 
 Must be changed every 60–90 days 
 Should be unique across all systems 
3.2 Prohibited Activities 
 Sharing passwords with anyone (including teammates or managers) 
 Writing passwords on paper or notes 
 Reusing the same password across personal and office systems 
3.3 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) 
 Mandatory for VPN, email, admin apps, cloud systems 
 Employees must not disable MFA 
 
4. Email Security 
4.1 Acceptable Use 
 Use official email only for work-related communication 
 Verify recipient before sending sensitive documents 
 Use encryption for confidential attachments 
4.2 Phishing & Malware Protection 
Employees must: 
 Not click unknown or suspicious links 
 Not download unsolicited attachments 
 Report suspicious emails to IT immediately 
 Never share credentials via email

4.3 Prohibited Email Activities 
 Forwarding company data to personal emails 
 Using personal devices for official emails without approval 
 Sending source code, client data, or internal documents externally without authorization 
 
5. VPN Usage 
5.1 Mandatory VPN 
Employees must use the company-approved VPN when: 
 Working from home 
 Accessing internal tools, servers, or cloud environments 
 Accessing code repositories, production data, or admin dashboards 
5.2 Rules for VPN Access 
 VPN credentials must not be shared 
 Use only company-owned or IT-approved devices 
 Disconnect VPN when not in use 
 Any unusual VPN activity will be monitored by IT 
5.3 Prohibited Use 
 Using VPN for personal browsing 
 Using third-party/unauthorized VPN services 
 
6. Remote Access Control 
6.1 Device & Network Requirements 
 Only company-issued devices should be used for remote work 
 Home Wi-Fi must be password-protected 
 Avoid using public Wi-Fi; if unavoidable, VPN is mandatory 
 Device screens must be password-protected 
6.2 Access Rights

 Access is granted on a need-to-know basis 
 Employees must not attempt to access systems they are not authorized for 
 Access is revoked immediately upon exit or role change 
6.3 Secure Workspace Practices (WFH/Remote) 
 Work should not be done in exposed or public spaces 
 Confidential calls should be taken privately 
 Personal family members should not access office devices 
 
7. Confidential Information Handling 
7.1 Definition of Confidential Information 
Includes but is not limited to: 
 Source code 
 Client data 
 Contracts & financials 
 Employee records 
 Business strategies 
 Login credentials, keys, tokens 
 R&D documents, designs, prototypes 
7.2 Rules for Handling Confidential Information 
Employees must: 
 Access only the data required for their job 
 Store confidential information in company-approved systems only 
 Not copy or store data on personal devices 
 Not upload office data to personal cloud drives (Google Drive, Dropbox, etc.) 
 Not share internal data externally without written approval 
7.3 Physical Document Security 
 Avoid printing confidential documents unless necessary 
 Store printed documents in secure locations 
 Shred documents after use 
7.4 Sharing Information 
 Share confidential data only with authorized individuals

 Use secure file sharing (OneDrive, SharePoint, encrypted email) 
 Verify identity before sharing over calls or chat 
 
8. Data Storage & Access Rules 
8.1 Approved Storage Systems 
 Company cloud platforms 
 Version control systems (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket) 
 Encrypted internal drives 
 Corporate email 
8.2 Prohibited Storage 
 Personal USB drives 
 Personal laptops or mobiles 
 Personal email or cloud storage 
 Social media, forums, or messaging apps 
 
9. Incident Reporting 
Employees must immediately report: 
 Lost or stolen laptop/device 
 Suspicious email or phishing attempts 
 Unauthorized login attempts 
 Data breach or accidental sharing 
 System malfunction affecting security 
Report to: 
IT Security Team / security@[company].com 
or your manager. 
Delays in reporting may result in disciplinary action. 
 
10. Violations & Disciplinary Action

Violations of this policy may result in: 
 Warning or reprimand 
 Revocation of system access 
 Suspension 
 Termination of employment 
 Legal action (in cases involving data theft or breach) 
Examples of violations: 
 Sharing credentials 
 Copying code outside company systems 
 Leaking confidential project information 
 Using unauthorized software 
 Tampering with company devices 
 
11. Employee Responsibilities 
Employees must: 
 Follow all security protocols 
 Keep devices and data safe 
 Attend mandatory security training 
 Protect client and company information 
 Report any breach immediately 
 
12. IT & Security Team Responsibilities 
The IT/Security team will: 
 Maintain secure infrastructure 
 Monitor access logs 
 Conduct periodic audits 
 Provide training and tools 
 Ensure compliance with legal & client requirements 
 
13. Policy Review

This policy is reviewed annually or after any major security incident, legal update, or 
organizational change. 
Updates will be communicated company-wide via email or HRMS.
